trans-unit.source: Service Chaining - Transit through peered VNet
trans-unit.target: Service Chaining - Transit through peered VNet

trans-unit.source: Although the use of system routes facilitates traffic automatically for your deployment, there are cases in which you want to control the routing of packets through a virtual appliance.
trans-unit.target: Although the use of system routes facilitates traffic automatically for your deployment, there are cases in which you want to control the routing of packets through a virtual appliance.

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, there are two VNets in a subscription, HubVNet and VNet1 as described in below diagram.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, there are two VNets in a subscription, HubVNet and VNet1 as described in below diagram.

trans-unit.source: You deploy Network Virtual Appliance(NVA) in VNet HubVNet.
trans-unit.target: You deploy Network Virtual Appliance(NVA) in VNet HubVNet.

trans-unit.source: After establishing VNet peering between HubVNet and VNet1, you can set up User Defined Routes and specify the next hop to NVA in the HubVNet.
trans-unit.target: After establishing VNet peering between HubVNet and VNet1, you can set up User Defined Routes and specify the next hop to NVA in the HubVNet.

trans-unit.source: For the simplicity, assume all VNets here are in the same subscription.
trans-unit.target: For the simplicity, assume all VNets here are in the same subscription.

trans-unit.source: But it also works for cross-subscription scenario.
trans-unit.target: But it also works for cross-subscription scenario.

trans-unit.source: The key property to enable Transit routing is the "Allow Forwarded Traffic" parameter.
trans-unit.target: The key property to enable Transit routing is the "Allow Forwarded Traffic" parameter.

trans-unit.source: This allows accepting and sending trafic from/to the NVA in the peered VNet.
trans-unit.target: This allows accepting and sending trafic from/to the NVA in the peered VNet.
